title-group.article-title: FAMILIAL ASSOCIATION OF ABSTINENT REMISSION FROM ALCOHOL USE DISORDER IN FIRST-DEGREE RELATIVES OF ALCOHOL-DEPENDENT TREATMENT-SEEKING PROBANDS

sec.title: BACKGROUND AND AIMS
sec.p: Studies that have included family history of alcohol use disorder (AUD) as a predictor of remission from AUD have yielded few significant results. The goals of this study were to estimate the association of persistent AUD, non-abstinent remission and abstinent remission (“AUD/remission status”) in a proband with AUD/remission status in a relative and to test whether this association differed in related and unrelated proband-relative pairs.

sec.title: DESIGN
sec.p: High-risk family study of alcohol dependence. Probands were recruited from treatment settings and relatives were invited to participate. Baseline assessments occurred between 1991–1998 with follow-up between 1996–2005. Half of probands were matched with a biological 1st-degree relative with lifetime AUD (related group) and half of probands were paired with an unrelated individual with lifetime AUD (unrelated group).

sec.title: SETTING
sec.p: Brooklyn, New York; Indianapolis, Indiana; Iowa City, Iowa; San Diego, California; Farmington, Connecticut; and St. Louis, Missouri, USA.

sec.title: PARTICIPANTS
sec.p: 606 probands (25.7% female, mean age 37.7) with baseline and follow-up data and 606 of their 1st degree relatives who had lifetime AUDs (45.8% female, mean age 36.2).

sec.title: MEASUREMENTS
sec.p: Persistent AUD, non-abstinent remission, and abstinent remission were based on self-report interview data on most recent AUD symptoms and alcohol consumption. Dependent variable was relatives’ AUD/remission status. Independent variable was probands’ AUD/remission status.

sec.title: FINDINGS
sec.p: 34.6% of probands and 20.6% of relatives were abstinent and 11.1% of probands and 22.8% of relatives were in non-abstinent remission. AUD/remission status was significantly correlated in related (r=.23, p=.0037) but not in unrelated pairs. A significant interaction of probands’ abstinent remission with a variable representing related (versus unrelated, p=.003) pairs suggested a familial association for abstinent remission. In related pairs, individuals with an abstinent proband were more likely to be abstinent themselves than were individuals whose proband had persistent AUD (relative risk ratio=3.27, 95% CI=1.56–6.85, p=.002); this association was not significant in unrelated pairs.

sec.title: CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: The likelihood of abstinent remission among people with alcohol use disorder (AUD) appears to be more than 3 times greater for individuals who are related to an abstinent proband versus those related to a proband with persistent AUD.
